Weights and Biases version: '0.8.21' Python version: 3.5.3 Operating System: GCP AI Notebook with Tensorflow 2.0 Environment Jupyter Lab
<denchmark-h:h3>Description</denchmark-h>
If I create a bar plot using matplotlib.pyplot and pass in a set of colors to use for each bar, it displays the plot correctly with the corresponding colors. When I log this plot to wandb, the plot displayed in wandb shows the correct bars but all the same color. Alternatively, if I log the plot to wandb as an image, it uploads the plot correctly with the corresponding colors. <denchmark-h:h3>What I Did</denchmark-h>
<denchmark-code>import numpy as np import matplotlib.pylplot as plt import seaborn as sns
lengths, modes = np.unique(counts, return_counts=True) pal = list(sns.color_palette("hls", len(lengths))) plt.bar(lengths[1:], modes[1:], color=pal) plt.xlabel('Visit Lengths') plt.ylabel('Frequency') wandb.log({'Visit Length Distribution' : plt}) </denchmark-code>

In addition, when I use plotly directly, it displays perfectly in Jupyter Lab but logs a blank graph to wandb. <denchmark-code>import numpy as np import plotly import seaborn as sns import plotly.graph_objects as go
plotly.offline.init_notebook_mode(connected=True) lengths, modes = np.unique(counts, return_counts=True) pal = list(sns.color_palette("hls", len(lengths))) colors = ['#%02x%02x%02x' % (int(r*255), int(g*255), int(b*255)) for (r,g,b) in pal]
fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Bar( x=lengths[1:], y=modes[1:], marker_color=colors )])
wandb.log({'Visit Length Distribution':fig}) </denchmark-code>

I think the first issue is a plotly issue. If I do: <denchmark-code>import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt, mpld3 import seaborn as sns import plotly.tools
lengths = [1,2,3,4] modes = [1,2,3,4] pal = list(sns.color_palette("hls", len(lengths))) fig ,ax = plt.subplots() ax.bar(lengths[1:], modes[1:], color=pal) fig.xlabel('Visit Lengths') fig.ylabel('Frequency') plotly = plotly.tools.mpl_to_plotly(fig) plotly </denchmark-code>
I get a chart without the colors

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/mpld3/mpld3>https://github.com/mpld3/mpld3</denchmark-link> seems to handle this case correctly - maybe we should switch <denchmark-link:https://github.com/vanpelt>@vanpelt</denchmark-link> - do you have any opinion?

the second code snippet worked great for me - I filled in some values: <denchmark-code>import numpy as np import plotly import seaborn as sns import plotly.graph_objects as go
wandb.init() plotly.offline.init_notebook_mode(connected=True) lengths, modes = [1,2,3,4], [1,2,3,4] pal = list(sns.color_palette("hls", len(lengths))) colors = ['#%02x%02x%02x' % (int(r*255), int(g*255), int(b*255)) for (r,g,b) in pal]
fig = go.Figure(data=[go.Bar( x=lengths[1:], y=modes[1:], marker_color=colors )])
wandb.log({'Visit Length Distribution':fig}) </denchmark-code>
<denchmark-link:https://app.wandb.ai/l2k2/course-v3-nbs_dl1/runs/pru2s82n?workspace=user-l2k2>https://app.wandb.ai/l2k2/course-v3-nbs_dl1/runs/pru2s82n?workspace=user-l2k2</denchmark-link>

I've narrowed down the issue: the cell fails when lengths and modes are initialized as numpy arrays. If I cast them into list types the plot will display correctly on the Wandb client window. Oddly enough, I can use numpy arrays and successfully display the plot in my notebook. Therefore, this likely has something to do with the way Wandb logs plots, possibly expecting only list data.

Thanks <denchmark-link:https://github.com/intermx-rwalden>@intermx-rwalden</denchmark-link> when we serialize to json we convert numpy arrays to histograms, but I thought I had made sure that didn't happen for plotly JSON. We clearly missed something here.
I have a branch that fixes this, you can use with: pip install --upgrade git+git://github.com/wandb/client.git@bug/plotly_np#egg=wandb we'll get this out in the next release.
This should be fixed now - thanks for the bug report!
